subject: Physical Fitness
title: How Tendons Work
description: A 1-minute de-risking session on How Tendons Work.

hook.text: Tendons connect muscle to bone. They transmit force, store energy, and are the most commonly injured connective tissue.

buildup.text: Tendons are made of collagen fibers arranged in parallel. This structure makes them incredibly strong under tension.

discovery.text: Unlike muscles, tendons have poor blood supply. This means they adapt slowly and heal slowly after injury.

twist.text: Tendons respond best to heavy, slow loading. Quick, bouncy movements build muscle but can irritate tendons.

climax.text: This mismatch â€” muscles adapting fast, tendons adapting slow â€” is why tendon injuries are so common in training.

punchline.text: Muscles strengthen in weeks. Tendons take months. Patience protects them.

quiz.question: Why do tendon injuries occur so frequently in training?
options: Tendons adapt much more slowly than muscles, creating a strength mismatch
Tendons are not affected by exercise
